journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part F: Journal of Rail and Rapid Transit

title-group.article-title: Current train control optimization methods with a view for application in heavy haul railways

contrib-group.aff: Centre for Railway Engineering, CQUniversity Australia, Rockhampton, Australia

author-notes.corresp: *Corresponding author: Building 70, Centre for Railway Engineering, CQUniversity Australia, Rockhampton, QLD 4702, Australia. email: m.mcclanachan@cqu.edu.au

abstract.p: Railway operators are continually increasing the length and weight of heavy haul trains to achieve reduced operating costs and increase network capacity. With longer and heavier trains, it becomes increasingly difficult for human operators to control the train optimally. The three main objectives of train control are minimizing journey time, minimizing energy usage, and minimizing in-train dynamics. This article reviews published train control optimization methods used in passenger, freight, and long heavy haul trains with a view of determining which methods would be best applied to the optimization of heavy haul train control.

sec.title: FUNDING
sec.p: The authors thank the Centre for Railway Engineering and the Queensland Government Smart Futures PhD scholarship for providing financial support for this study.
